This is a great idea! I've been wanting this!

I have an idea on how to implement plasma without a huge tech update: 

You throw a nether quartz item into fire and the fire absorbs into the nether quartz, which transforms it into orange plasma. The plasma could not be carried with bare hands, otherwise you'd get the wither effect. It must only be transported in a minecart. To craft with it, you put it in an oven as fuel and then add your iron tool of choice. The charge is transferred into the iron and you get an energy tool. This can also be done with shields but should not be done with iron armor. That would be a fatal mistake. It would lose durability while you, the player with the armor on, get killed by wither effect level 2. 

Now, energy tools would be faster than their iron counterparts and have the same strength (except the pickaxe that can mine diamond level), but it would have less durability. The durability can be recharged in a furnace as long as the item isn't fully used up.
This is all copyrightable stuff, they cannot do this if they wanted to, plus IRL Plasma can only last a fraction of a second they the plasma would disappear.
Yis

Nether stars are so hard to get! They need to do something better. I think the beacon is a perfect teleport block. 'Beacon' even sounds like you should be able to teleport to it, like in that map mod with waypoints. I think you should stand on a beacon block, select another beacon and then click to teleport. The beacon already has a UI so it could be modified to allow you to activate it. Perhaps each teleport require one ender pearl to be put into the beacon.

I love this idea! I have two changes, though:

 

First, I think it should cost resources for each use, not just to build. I'm thinking it should require a number of ender pearls based on the distance. Something like p = sqrt(d/256), where p is the number of ender pearls, and d is the distance between the two portals. So the pattern would look something like this:

  • 1 pearl (p) gets up to 256 blocks (d)
  • 2, up to 1024
  • 3, up to 9216
  • ...
  • 16 (max) up to 65,536 blocks

I'm envisioning a UI kind of like a hopper or dispenser, where the player could store pearls for future use. The player could also feed pearls into the teleporter with a hopper. To avoid abuse this form of transport would have to be prohibited in the Nether, and telepads in the End could not connect to telepads in the Overworld.

 

Second, this absolutely needs to be limited to end game players who have been to the end. I think an appropriate recipe would require purpur. The crafting recipe would look something like this:

O O O

P D P

P N P

(O = blank, N = nether star, P = purpur block, D = diamond)

If developers feel this recipe should be more costly, they could require a diamond block instead of a single diamond, and shulker shells instead of purpur.

 

@Martin Nether stars are hard to get, but the ability to teleport is very powerful. Requiring players to choose between a beacon or a teleporter, instead of giving them both for free, means they have to make an interesting gameplay decision based on their particular situation and needs.

I had a very similar idea, however the crafting recipie was:

NDN
DSD
OOO

Where:

  • N = Nothing
  • D = Diamond
  • S = Nether Star
  • O = Obsidian

And each portal had two words: one to identify itself and another to identify its destination. That way "a" can go to "b" which can go to "c" which can go back to "a".

And in my idea the teleporter was a block that would go above a nether portal like shape that was made of iron blocks.

I also agree with @Galiantus idea about putting ender pearls into the teleporter to change the maximum distance.

Also, the portal would be an immovable block in JE and movable in BE.
hopefully they will.

Having the texture change for the different number of books on the Shelf would be good for builders as well. Also, having Spruce Bookshelves should be added ASAP. I'm honestly surprised it didn't come in 1.13 with the trapdoors and buttons.

There's actually a really good reason to add this to the game: it would make it possible for anyone to beat the game in PEACEFUL difficulty. Remember, you can't find or craft eyes of ender currently since blazes don't spawn (and therefore you can't get blaze powder). If you could take the eyes of ender out of an end portal, you would be able to find several strongholds, steal the eyes from the unfinished portals there, and then use them to complete at least one portal in another stronghold once you collect enough of them. In fact, once you had a single eye of ender, you could even risk throwing it to help you find one of the other strongholds.

Currently, the only way to beat the game in peaceful difficulty is to get really lucky and have a seed that generates an end portal with all 12 eyes present. That's ridiculous. By allowing players to remove end eyes from existing end portals, it would allow players to gain access to The End (and by extension, shulker boxes and elytra) while playing on peaceful.
Also, removing an eye of ender from a completed portal should deactivate it, obviously. (Or perhaps it shouldn't be possible to remove ender eyes from a completed portal.)

It sounds like a good idea. Players could beat the game in peaceful (albeit they would need to find about 120 strongholds to get all the eyes necessary). Comparators could also detect if an end portal frame has an eye in it or not. That functionality isn't really useful if once the eye is in the frame, it couldn't be removed.

Great idea. I would really like to use this for getting to the end in peaceful as outlined above. It would also be quite difficult/ time consuming. I had about a 25% chance of finding an eye on a portal frame in my seed. Not all strongholds have an eye spawned and not all strongholds even have an end frame. Very good idea!
Perhaps, when you put the tool belt in a hotbar slot, alt + scroll wheel could cycle through items stored in the tool belt, so you wouldn't have to take items in and out of the tool belt

Just having those few extra inventory slots not taken up by tools seems like a great idea, early game i tend to have most of my hotbar filled, and later on they just take up a ton of space in my ender chest + shulker box storage

I created this account to just to suggest a tool/weapon belt after I seen the traffic on that OP idea of an early game backpack. The chest mule already exists and then there are shulkers for endgame that make the accomplishment feel most rewarding compared to any endgame that I've experienced so far. (I just beat the game for the first time). I love the idea of the scroll wheel with a mouse or a PS5 touchpad in my case to access the contents.
A nice idea, of course, but in my opinion, the belt can coexist with the backpack just fine.

I think wearing the tool belt should simply add more slots to your hot bar. (Maybe 4 slots?) Adding inventory slots seems like a task better equipped for a potential backpack item. A toolbelt and the hotbar serve the same purpose, which is to provide immediate access to a handful of items. Therefore it makes sense for the tool belt to expand the hotbar. Expanding the hotbar would also be far more intuitive, rather than requiring complicated new UI/controls for storing items within items. Lastly, I think that any items stored in the extra slots should be displayed on the belt model.

I think that mining or interacting with a block would call up the best tool (i.e. LMB on waxed copper would call pickaxe, RMB would call axe). If a player punches a mob, it would call up the sword, trident or axe, depending on what is "closest" to the selected slot. Right-clicking a mob (without interacting with it) would call the Bow, Crossbow or Trident. Right-clicking on thin air would call the Spyglass, Bow, Crossbow or Trident. To go back to your normal hotbar, simply switch to a different hotbar slot.

The tool belt should be an equippable item (add new armor slot for belts) and this will increase your hotbar length

- Tiers
--Tier 1: Leather belt (1 slot)
--Tier 2: Iron buckle belt (2 slots)
--Tier 3: Gold buckle belt (3 slots)
--Tier 4: Diamond buckle belt (4 slots)
--Tier 5: Netherite buckle belt (5 slots)

- Crafting
Belts are crafted with 2 leather and one ingot.
Initially, belts do not add any slots. To add a slot, you must first craft the belt, then add one of the following for one additional slot: 1 ingot, or 1 empty bottle, or 1 wool, or 1 leather.

- Slot types
Each ingot slot will let you carry a non-stackable tool, each wool slot will let you carry a stack of seeds/saplings/food/etc, each bottle will let you carry a potion, & each leather will let you carry arrows. This give players more customization to their play style. You can mix slots on a belt.

Belts will not add armor and don't necessarily need a visual representation. If belts are visual, different skin options can be available through unlocks or the MC store.

Belts will drop upon death along with their items. They do not act like shulker boxes. If the belt is unequipped, it will not contain the items, you must have the inventory space available to hold the items or prevent belt removal.

TLDR;
5 belt tiers: Leather, Iron, Gold, Diamond, Netherite
4 slot types: Tool, Potion, small items, arrows
You can mix and match slot types
Belts will not hold items unless equipped
Belts drop their items upon death

Tnt barrels work differently. When you place the barrel, you can open the barrel to put whatever items you want in it. Every item put inside the barrel will be binded to the slot, so it can never be removed again. The tnt barrel can be picked up again similar to a shulker box. When a tnt barrel explodes, any items inside of it will explode with it. This would allow players to make their own personalized tnt or more powerful tnt.

It should pretty much be like an item frame, but look nicer.

I suggest renaming it from Glass Casing into a Display Case since the Caves and Cliffs Update will also feature Archaeological digs. You can't have a good museum with your archaeological findings if you can't display it in a Display Case.

This will be a 3D version for the Item frames.

Recipe for it 6 Glass Panes and 3 Wooden Slabs. This recipe is for a Display Case that can only contain items/blocks that are about less than a Block in size. You can adjust its size by putting multiple Display Cases in the Crafting Table. Cases arranged in a 4x4 square will house items/blocks that are less than 2 blocks in size. Arranged in a 1x2 rectangle will house blocks that are less than 1 block wide but less than 2 blocks high, The maximum size is 3x3.

To place an item in the Display Case, just right click on it similar to an Item Frame. You can break it with a Pick Axe and it drops the item itself, unlike Glass. If there's an Item displayed there, it also drops the item.

I think that copper tools and armor should oxidize whenever they haven't taken any durability damage for a long enough amount of time, but a level of oxidation gets removed from them for every use, and higher oxidation gives better armor/efficiency/damage depending on the item. (so an Oxidized Copper Chestplate gives a bit more armor than a Weathered Copper Chestplate, but receiving a single hit would turn the former into the latter; for tools, higher oxidation grants them higher block-breaking speed and a bit of extra damage)

Ingame copper tools are already stronger than what copper tools would be, copper is a soft metal that deforms easly not ideal for any use in terms of mining or protection

copper items being stronger than iron make no sense gameplay wise since copper is more common than iron
